title: Audio and Acoustical Engineering: How could small speakers be used to produce deep bass sounds? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hi there. This might sound like a very basic answer, so I apologize if it doesn't quite hit the bulls-eye to this question. The reasons why smaller speakers don't have a good Low Frequency response can be a mix of some of the following explanations:  1) Low Frequencies are produced but to be heard by a human ear have to have a minimum magnitude (Further: Fletcher-Munson Curves),2) Smaller speakers (Direct Speakers) are physically incapable of pushing the volume of air that allow lower frequencies to be reproduced at the magnitude they should be. 3) The lower the frequency the longer the wavelength i.e. the more space it needs before it completes atleast one cycle at which point it can be heard as a vibrating band of air. Most speakers we find are direct speakers - which are by-far the most inefficient type of speaker possible. In most commercial hi-fi audio systems, the speaker sizes are moderate (still smaller than the golden sizes of 10", and 12" cones for guitar amps etc), yet a fairly balanced low end is reproduced - this is because commercial audio manufacturers traditionally adopt indirect speakers using techniques like Horn-loading and reflex ports. Reflex ports are probably best done by the manufacturers due to trouble with phase alignment, material and mathematics - but can be a good step forward - but not to say its not been done before, and the results aren't nearly there yet.  Using something like horn-loading can be a way of hacking the phone/laptop's speakers to help with Lower frequency - but this would automatically have limitations with size and bulkiness to the construct given the trade-off of how low it can go. Imagine two horns sitting on each speaker of your laptop - making it look like a modern gramophone player, not to mention also obstructing your screen a good deal I reckon. Not to guarantee this will revive the dead lower end completely. And then adding on, there's always trouble with the materials, leakages, damping, etc...  Thats to my knowledge so far. Hope this helps.. Here are some pictures of horn-loading for a good low end on a fairly normal sized (probably a 2 - 4" woofer cone)... just to give you an idea of how horn-loading never ceases to end in possibilities.      notice the bigger white cone at the very back - the whole white wall more or less.

There are a few “tricks” that are used to “push things” a bit further. But this is done with a series of Compromises. Loudspeakers convert electrical signals into mechanical motion. This motion will cause air molecules in front and to the back of it to vibrate. Rather than simply pushing the molecules out of the way, a wave is created. This wave influences each little area of air molecules as it passes through. As the sound wave “moves”, first the air molecules are pressed tighter together (compression) and then pulled farther apart (rarefaction). The alternating high and low pressure will move the eardrum, and we perceive this oscillation as sound.  You can not dramatically increase the size of the cone of loudspeaker drivers, without having to increase the cabinet size you will need, in order to get the most out of the driver, or to fit it in. But you can create a smaller loudspeaker with a longer throw.  In a loudspeaker long throw refers to the ability of a speaker cone to travel long distances “in and out”, ideally without encountering nonlinearities in its response. It is difficult to make a single speaker that can reproduce all frequencies equally well. Therefore some compromises are taken when building a small full range driver that will respond “well” to lower frequencies. It will do it in determent to the other frequencies.  So these small speakers when, and, if measured, are not as amazing in their response, as you assume or perceive they are. To the average listener they may “sound” great but that is not entirely true. If compared with true Higher Fidelity loudspeakers they actually sound,…well,… not so good at all. There is a lot of information missing, and the mids and highs will “suffer” a lot in the overall presentation. This is not a “new technology” it is almost like creating a woofer that “can” respond to a wider range of frequencies. A good full range does not usually have a long throw.  In addition passive radiators can also be used.  There are plenty of “solutions” with passive radiators and they are also not a “new technology” A passive radiator is a speaker without the magnet, and electronic structure attached to it. A passive radiator speaker is a simple device used to increase the low frequency response (Bass) of a speaker system. When used properly, a passive radiator can give a speaker system the comparable performance characteristics of a larger system. They are used where there is not enough space for a port or vent system.  After the development of the Ice Power amplifier from Bang & Olufsen several related or derived technologies for amplification have been created. Some with greater or lesser quality or success, but the physical size of the amplifier needed to reach a certain amount of power can be considerably reduced.  Another “trick” is the use of software at the preamplifier stage that can enhance the response of a given or a particular range of frequencies. It has long been realised that auditory perception has a complex relationship to the sound that causes it and the discipline of psychoacoustics has established a body of knowledge explaining this relationship. More recently, audio system designers have been utilising these findings to maximise the performance of their systems. The techniques of perceptual coding have been developed to focus on designing systems for the way we hear, and allow the balance of efficiency and quality to be maximised.  Examples of successful implementations are the MPEG audio compression system, the Dolby AC-3 home theatre system and MaxxBass, a signal processing technology that, powerfully exploits psychoacoustic phenomena to recreate the sensation of low frequency sound without the necessity of covering the whole low frequency range. Essentially, it is a patented audio signal processing algorithm expressed in analogue or digital form. Correctly implemented it can extend the apparent low range of the loudspeaker by up to one and a half octaves with no loss of efficiency, no increase in power input and no increase in size. To understand how this is achieved it is best to briefly outline some theory. MaxxBass exploits the psychoacoustic phenomenon of the ‘missing fundamental’. This phenomenon involves the pitch perception of complex tones. Investigating the auditory perception of combination tones, Schouten showed that complex periodic sounds with no energy at the fundamental may still give a clear pitch sensation at the fundamental. This would indicate that low pitches may be perceived via those neural channels that normally respond to the high or middle frequency components of a signal.  In the end your brain is just being tricked. This makes you belie you are listening to a great audio performance from the speaker, when, in fact, that is not usually the case.  Psychoacoustics is the scientific study of sound perception. More specifically, it is the branch of science studying the psychological and physiological responses associated with sound (including speech and music). Psychoacoustics received its name from a field within psychology which deals with all kinds of human perceptions.  Sources: Psychoacoustics and the auditory masking phenomenon http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.524.4796&rep=rep1&type=pdf

If you put many small speakers together in an array you can theoretically displace the required amount of air to achieve good low frequency response. The problem is controlling each individual speaker so that it contributes and not detracts from the sound. If you use junk speakers you will get a poor result. Use high quality products and you could get a great result. So building this array will be wonderful yes? Except having to use all those small expensive drivers, constructing a special cabinet, wire it all up and heavy duty amp… Wait, why not just use one or two large speakers and a smaller cabinet and a normal amp? Well if you have your heart set on small speakers then you have to come up with a more ingenious way to do this. Several decades ago Keith O Johnson built a custom three - 5 inch driver RF servo-driven subwoofer using (I think it was 5 inch) super long throw voice coils. And it was a room shaking speaker. Point being low frequency sound needs a lot of air displacement to work by what ever means possible and he did it. Today the technology has moved on and now we have MEMs (Micro ElectroMechnical Systems) speaker arrays. So be prepared to come full circle with “The Wall of Sound” again very soon. Think tiny subwoofers the size of your cell phone. We shall see.

By ultilising psychoacoustic trickery. Waves Audio developed Maxxbass to do this. In basic, the fundamental frequency of low frequencies said small speaker CAN produce is measured. Then it produces multiples of the fundamental near to the lower frequency that the listener wants to interpret as bass and your ear/brain thus 'hears' low bass. But you are not actually hearing it, your brain is simply making up the missing frequency because it is hearing a partial frequency that belongs to that bass frequency, so your brain decides “hey, bass!” and so it duly processes it. An everyday example would be when you talk to people on the phone, they still sound the way they do in person. A person with a deep gruff voice will still sound the same despite the fact the tiny speaker in your phone couldn't possibly be reproducing those frequencies. Your brain makes the rest up. Sorry I couldn't give a more technical explanation. Its been years since I was at University.

If by small you mean in terms of radiating surface of the driver, there are two basic ways to produce more low frequency acoustic energy. One is to increase the excursion of the surface, that is the forward and backward distance the surface can move. The other is to increase the number of drivers, so that the total effective radiating surface area is increased. Of course these strategies can be combined. There are also enclosure design techniques that take advantage of the resonance of the air mass inside the enclosure. These can be tuned to increase the effective power radiated in a selected frequency range. In general however it’s at the expense of power outside that range, so the total power capacity isn’t necessarily increased. And as some previous answers have pointed out, horn loading can potentially improve the efficiency of energy transfer.

Computers have made much easier the calculations to optimize the sound in a little speaker by matching the cabinet to the parameters of a speaker. Small speakers by design don't need a large cabinet for their best use. Some may use equalization to boost or cut certain frequencies to improve the human perception of the way they sound. Bose does this a lot. It makes the sound innacurate, but more impressive. But if you actually test these little speakers, you will find that while that little speaker is doing all it can do, making use of all of the technology possible to make it sound as good as it can be, its still a small speaker with major limitations, and will not compare with a larger, similarly well designed speaker.

Computer-aided engineering of the drivers has enabled lower resonant frequencies and extreme linear travel (Xmax).  DSP control allows the driver to be pushed to its limit, but not beyond, so the "safety mechanisms" can be removed without fear of distortion / damage.  As you turn up the volume on these small speakers, multiband compression is used to limit the lowest frequencies - since they require the most excursion - without compressing the rest of the audio band.  Watch a Harman engineer explain it here (but don't listen to the interviewer, he really doesn't understand what he's saying):   Another technique commonly employed for squeezing low bass out of a small box is pairing an active driver with one or more Passive radiator (speaker)

There now seem to be a wave of small (think bluetooth) speakers that sound amazingly full range but are no larger than a soda can. I think we can all rest assured that the laws of physics have not been circumvented - big bass still needs a bigger box than a soda can. The apparent bass (and full range) response from those speakers today, notwithstanding their high-tech innards, is still no match against the sound from a 1970s Grundig portable radio containing a full range speaker. The perception might be more about being surprised by their small size rather than absolute fidelity which is actually quite terrible.

Diaphragm-based loudspeakers are restricted to displace no more air than their own volume, which becomes a problem in small portable devices. Developing an air pump-based loudspeaker with a pressurized air tank to enable displacing more air than its own volume would eliminate this problem. Lysholm-type twin screw rotary pump seems to have the right properties for this.

They don’t, but they’re getting better at fooling us into thinking those bass fundamentals are there. The availability of DSP and EQ in general helps. Jambox uses a passive radiator that’s one whole side of their enclosure, with mass loading by attaching the battery to the passive radiator. I think Soundmatters came up with that idea, and it works (up to a point). The overall Jambox tonal balance is pleasing, and a little midbass bump (common in small bookshelf speakers as well) gives a little more bass harmonic information to allow your brain to fool itself into thinking there’s some lower bass. Here’s a short teardown to show you what’s inside these nice little boxes. Jawbone Jambox Bluetooth Mobile Speaker Teardown

There are several methods — two that stand out are electronic equalization and arranging multiple small drivers to work together to provide the rough equivalent of a single large driver. Here’s an expertly designed “high-end” (nearly $20K!) system that employs both those techniques: Advantages of the IDS Technology

If you want the bass to be deep, clean and loud enough to be audible you have two choices. Use a large quantity of small speakers or use your small speakers as trades for a set of properly sized speakers.

Just about all of the equations and even speaker enclosure designs have been around for 20 years, even 30 or 40 years back.  I have books going back to the late 1970s describing passive radiators, transmission lines, and nonlinear baffles. Thiele-Small parameters have been used to design systems for decades.  What has changed is the cost of the technology, and in some cases, new materials.

Hoffmanns iron law, pick any two listed below -deep bass -high sensitivuty -small enclosure you cant have all three so a small enclosure and deep bass means you have to sacrifice sensitivity, meaning you just need more power for yor speakers. This will increase distortion, so no matter what you pick, all speaker designs have their trade offs.
